MSfinance1:
There was sufficient funding

(In most cases I have been able to conduct research on surveillance by intelligence agencies)
MSapp1specify: A story I commissioned and edited about Russian disinformation was shortlisted for the British Journalism Awards
MSsoc5other: Court actions taken by NGOs, particularly Privacy International, Liberty and Big Brother Watch has led to important and significant disclosures about UK intelligence operations. So court and tribunal proceedings often prompt stories.
MSimpact2other:
I think the importance of publishing national security stories is cumulative. Its rare than one story has an impact on its own but over time they lead to pressure for greater accountability and transparency. 

It is often difficult for other publications to follow-up stories. I have found it difficult to follow up other people's stories, for example, without having access to the source material behind them.
MSprotectops4: Technological tools help to protect my identity to some extent, but an attacker with sufficient power may eventually be able to bypass my technological safeguards.
MSprotectleg1:
Sometimes

(When I cover intelligence, there is reason to be concerned regarding the protection of my sources from time to time)
MSconstraintcen3: Maybe once or twice.  Generally I expect a no-comment for stories on surveillance matters. With stories relating to law enforcement and surveillance I am more likely to make an approach.
MSconstraintself1ot: I am aware that some publications are less willing than others to write on matters of national security.
MSattitude1: Intelligence agencies are necessary and legitimate institutions of democratic states, even though they may sometimes overstep their legal mandates.
MSattitude2: Intelligence oversight is mostly effective, however its institutional design needs reform for oversight practitioners to reliably uncover past misconduct and prevent future misconduct.
